title: DoDAO Contributor
summary: This course will introduce you to the values, vision, and background of DoDAO, as well as provide guidance on how to contribute in DoDAO
details: The  course/handbook outlines the values on which we work at DoDAO. This course covers topics such as job responsibilities, compensation, benefits, working hours, and code of conduct. It provides a clear framework for contributors to understand what is expected of them and what they can expect from DoDAO, promoting a positive and productive work environment for all.

topics.title: About DoDAO
topics.details:
In this chapter, we will discuss the current state of DoDAO. As a dynamic startup, we are constantly evolving and adjusting our immediate milestones, but our overarching vision remains unchanged: to be the preeminent technology company in the realm of Customer/User Education. 

To achieve this, we collaborate with top-tier organizations to create educational websites that inform and engage their customers or users. Our commitment to excellence drives us to work with the best partners in this space.

explanations.title: Values
explanations.details:
At our company, we strive to uphold several important values that shape our organizational culture and guide our work.

1. **Continuous Learning** - First and foremost, we are committed to continuous learning. We believe that in order to deliver the best possible results, we must always seek to improve our skills and knowledge. 

2. **Ownership** - Ownership means, when working on a task or functionality, you will figure out a way to complete the work. Its fine to do it wrong, but its important to try it and make progress.  

3. **High-quality Work** - We also place a strong emphasis on delivering high-quality work. Learning is the foundation of quality, and we approach our work with a commitment to iterative improvement. We start with a basic level of quality that gets the ball rolling, but we are always working towards achieving top quality.

4. **Fun** - We want our contributors to have the opportunity to work on projects that interest them and to feel a sense of fulfillment in their work.

5. **Communication** - Finally, we value clear and effective communication within our organization. It is essential that our contributors are transparent about how much time they can work and any other commitments they may have. This helps us to plan and collaborate effectively, and ensures that everyone is on the same page about upcoming projects and deadlines.

topics.title: Introduction
topics.details: Smart contract auditing is the process of reviewing and testing the source code of a smart contract to identify any potential vulnerabilities or security issues. This can include checking for errors in the code, evaluating the contract's overall design and architecture, and testing the contract's functionality to ensure that it performs as intended. The goal of a smart contract audit is to ensure that the contract is secure and reliable, and that it will function as intended when deployed on a blockchain network.

questions.content: What is Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework for rapidly building custom user interfaces.

choices.content: A utility-first CSS framework for rapidly building custom user interfaces
A JavaScript library for building user interfaces
A CSS preprocessor like Sass or Less
A CSS framework for building responsive web applications

questions.content: How do you install Tailwind CSS via npm?
questions.explanation: To install Tailwind CSS via npm, run `npm install tailwindcss`.

questions.content: Which command generates a default configuration file for Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The command 'npx tailwindcss init' generates a default configuration file for Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: What is the purpose of the @tailwind directive in a CSS file?
questions.explanation: The @tailwind directive is used to inject Tailwind's base, components, and utilities styles into your CSS.

choices.content: To inject Tailwind's base, components, and utilities styles into your CSS
To generate a responsive grid system

questions.content: What is the purpose of the @apply directive in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The @apply directive is used to inline any existing utility classes into your own custom CSS.

choices.content: To generate media queries for responsive design
To inline any existing utility classes into your own custom CSS

questions.content: How do you customize your configuration in a Tailwind CSS project?
questions.explanation: To customize your configuration in a Tailwind CSS project, you should modify the tailwind.config.js file.

questions.content: Which of the following is NOT a default breakpoint in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The 'xl2' breakpoint is not a default breakpoint in Tailwind CSS. The default breakpoints are 'sm', 'md', 'lg', and 'xl'.

questions.content: How do you create a custom utility class in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: To create a custom utility class in Tailwind CSS, you should add the new class to the 'extend' section in tailwind.config.js.

choices.content: Add the new class to the 'utilities' section in tailwind.config.js
Add the new class to the 'extend' section in tailwind.config.js
Add the new class to the 'variants' section in tailwind.config.js
Add the new class to the 'plugins' section in tailwind.config.js

questions.content: What is the purpose of the @screen directive in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The @screen directive is used to create media queries for responsive design based on the defined breakpoints.

choices.content: To create media queries for responsive design based on the defined breakpoints
To generate a responsive grid system

questions.content: Which of the following Tailwind CSS utility classes sets the font weight to bold?
questions.explanation: The 'font-bold' utility class sets the font weight to bold in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: What does the 'mx-auto' utility class do in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The 'mx-auto' utility class in Tailwind CSS sets the left and right margins of an element to 'auto', which centers the element horizontally within its container.

choices.content: Sets the top and bottom margins to 'auto'
Sets the left and right margins to 'auto'
Sets the width of the element to 'auto'
Sets the height of the element to 'auto'

questions.content: Which utility class in Tailwind CSS sets the display property to 'flex'?
questions.explanation: The 'flex' utility class in Tailwind CSS sets the display property of an element to 'flex'.

questions.content: How do you add a hover effect to the background color of an element using Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: To add a hover effect to the background color of an element using Tailwind CSS, you can use the 'hover:bg-{color}' utility class, where '{color}' is replaced by the desired color.

questions.content: How do you set the width of an element to 50% using Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: To set the width of an element to 50% using Tailwind CSS, you can use the 'w-1/2' utility class.

questions.content: How do you set the position property of an element to 'relative' using Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: To set the position property of an element to 'relative' using Tailwind CSS, you can use the 'relative' utility class.

questions.content: What is the purpose of the @variants directive in a Tailwind CSS configuration file?
questions.explanation: The @variants directive in a Tailwind CSS configuration file is used to generate responsive, hover, focus, and other variants of your custom utility classes.

choices.content: To generate responsive, hover, focus, and other variants of your custom utility classes

questions.content: How do you set the flex-grow property of an element to '1' using Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: To set the flex-grow property of an element to '1' using Tailwind CSS, you can use the 'flex-grow' utility class.

questions.content: What is the default font family used in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The default font family used in Tailwind CSS is 'sans-serif'.

questions.content: Which of the following is NOT a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for controlling font size?
questions.explanation: The 'fs-normal' utility class is not a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for controlling font size.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding a box shadow to an element?
questions.explanation: The 'shadow-md' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding a box shadow to an element.

questions.content: Which of the following Tailwind CSS utility classes can be used to add a border to an element?
questions.explanation: The 'border' and 'border-{size}' utility classes can be used to add a border to an element, where '{size}' is replaced by the desired border size.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding padding to all sides of an element?
questions.explanation: The 'p-{size}' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding padding to all sides of an element, where '{size}' is replaced by the desired padding size.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding margin to all sides of an element?
questions.explanation: The 'm-{size}' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding margin to all sides of an element, where '{size}' is replaced by the desired margin size.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for making an element text-align center?
questions.explanation: The 'text-center' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for making an element text-align center.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for making an element text-transform uppercase?
questions.explanation: The 'uppercase' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for making an element text-transform uppercase.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for making an element text-decoration underline?
questions.explanation: The 'underline' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for making an element text-decoration underline.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the text color of an element to red?
questions.explanation: The 'text-red-500' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the text color of an element to red.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the background color of an element to green?
questions.explanation: The 'bg-green-500' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the background color of an element to green.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding a rounded border to an element?
questions.explanation: The 'rounded-{size}' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for adding a rounded border to an element, where '{size}' is replaced by the desired border radius size.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for displaying an element as a flex container?
questions.explanation: The 'flex' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for displaying an element as a flex container.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for vertically centering an element within its container?
questions.explanation: The 'items-center' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for vertically centering an element within its container.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the width of an element to 50%?
questions.explanation: The 'w-1/2' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the width of an element to 50%.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the height of an element to 200 pixels?
questions.explanation: The 'h-200' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the height of an element to 200 pixels.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font size of an element to 20 pixels?
questions.explanation: The 'text-20' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font size of an element to 20 pixels.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font family of an element to 'Helvetica Neue'?
questions.explanation: The 'font-sans' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font family of an element to the default sans-serif font, which is typically 'Helvetica Neue' or a similar font.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font weight of an element to bold?
questions.explanation: The 'font-bold' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font weight of an element to bold.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the background color of an element to red?
questions.explanation: The 'bg-red-500' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the background color of an element to red.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the border color of an element to gray?
questions.explanation: The 'border-gray-500' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the border color of an element to gray.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the margin of an element to 20 pixels on all sides?
questions.explanation: The 'm-20' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the margin of an element to 20 pixels on all sides.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the padding of an element to 10 pixels on all sides?
questions.explanation: The 'p-10' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the padding of an element to 10 pixels on all sides.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the width of an element to 50% of its parent element's width?
questions.explanation: The 'w-1/2' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the width of an element to 50% of its parent element's width.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the height of an element to 100 pixels?
questions.explanation: The 'h-100' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the height of an element to 100 pixels.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the maximum width of an element to 500 pixels?
questions.explanation: The 'max-w-500' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the maximum width of an element to 500 pixels.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the display property of an element to none?
questions.explanation: The 'hidden' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the display property of an element to none.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font size of an element to 16 pixels?
questions.explanation: The 'text-base' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font size of an element to 16 pixels.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font weight of an element to bold?
questions.explanation: The 'font-bold' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the font weight of an element to bold.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the text color of an element to gray?
questions.explanation: The 'text-gray-500' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the text color of an element to gray.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for vertically centering an element within its parent element?
questions.explanation: The 'flex items-center justify-center' utility classes are a valid Tailwind CSS utility classes for vertically centering an element within its parent element.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a full-width container with a maximum width of 1200 pixels and a left and right margin of auto?
questions.explanation: The 'max-w-screen-xl mx-auto' utility classes are a valid Tailwind CSS utility classes for creating a full-width container with a maximum width of 1200 pixels and a left and right margin of auto.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a gradient background on an element?
questions.explanation: The 'bg-gradient-to-r' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a gradient background on an element.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a border with a width of 2 pixels and a color of gray?
questions.explanation: The 'border-2 border-gray-500' utility classes are a valid Tailwind CSS utility classes for creating a border with a width of 2 pixels and a color of gray.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the primary color of a theme to blue?
questions.explanation: The 'bg-primary-blue' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the primary color of a theme to blue.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a dark mode theme?
questions.explanation: The 'dark' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a dark mode theme.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a hover effect on a button with a primary color of green?
questions.explanation: The 'hover:bg-primary-green-dark' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a hover effect on a button with a primary color of green.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a light mode theme with a primary color of pink?
questions.explanation: The 'bg-light-primary-pink' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for creating a light mode theme with a primary color of pink.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid way to define a CSS variable in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The '--my-var: red;' syntax is a valid way to define a CSS variable in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid way to use a CSS variable in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The 'bg-var(--my-var)' utility class is a valid way to use a CSS variable in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the value of a CSS variable to a specific color?
questions.explanation: The 'text-my-var-red' utility class is a valid Tailwind CSS utility class for setting the value of a CSS variable to a specific color.

questions.content: What is the advantage of using CSS variables in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The advantage of using CSS variables in Tailwind CSS is that they allow for easy theming and customization of the design without having to modify the underlying HTML or JavaScript.

choices.content: They allow for faster rendering of the page.
They allow for more complex animations.
They allow for better compatibility with older browsers.
They allow for easy theming and customization of the design without having to modify the underlying HTML or JavaScript.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid way to define a custom utility class in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The '.my-class { color: red; }' syntax is a valid way to define a custom utility class in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid way to include a custom utility class in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The '@import "path/to/my-utilities.css";' syntax is a valid way to include a custom utility class in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: Which of the following is a valid way to create a reusable component in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The 'class="btn btn-primary"' syntax is a valid way to create a reusable component in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: What is the advantage of creating reusable components in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The advantage of creating reusable components in Tailwind CSS is that they can help to maintain consistency in the design and can save time by reducing the amount of code that needs to be written.

choices.content: They allow for more complex animations.
They can help to maintain consistency in the design and can save time by reducing the amount of code that needs to be written.
They improve the performance of the website.
They increase the security of the website.

questions.content: What is the syntax for creating a new component in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The syntax for creating a new component in Tailwind CSS is '.component-name { ... }'.

questions.content: What is the recommended way to create a reusable component in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The recommended way to create a reusable component in Tailwind CSS is to use the 'extend' feature.

choices.content: By duplicating the code of an existing component.
By using a CSS preprocessor like Sass or Less.
By creating a new CSS file for each component.
By using the 'extend' feature in Tailwind CSS.

questions.content: What is the syntax for extending an existing class in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The syntax for extending an existing class in Tailwind CSS is '.new-class-name { @extend .existing-class-name; }'.

questions.content: What is the purpose of the @apply directive in Tailwind CSS?
questions.explanation: The purpose of the @apply directive in Tailwind CSS is to apply a set of styles defined in a utility class to a new class.

choices.content: To include an external CSS file in the project.
To apply a set of styles defined in a utility class to a new class.
To define a new utility class.
To extend an existing utility class.

topics.title: DoDAO - Dev
topics.details: This chapter explains all the basic skills you need to have to be a DoDAO developer

questions.content: How do you add a message to your git commit?
questions.explanation: The '-m' flag is used with 'git commit' command to add a message to the commit.

questions.content: What command is used to save changes to the local repository in Git?
questions.explanation: The 'git commit' command is used to save your changes to the local repository.

questions.content: What command is used to stage changes for a commit in Git?
questions.explanation: The 'git add' command is used to stage changes for a commit in Git.

topics.title: Github
topics.details: This chapter explains all the basic git knowledge you need to have to be a DoDAO developer

questions.content: What is GitHub primarily used for?
questions.explanation: GitHub is primarily used for version control and collaboration on software development projects.

questions.content: What is Git?
questions.explanation: Git is a distributed version control system that allows multiple people to work on the same project simultaneously.

questions.content: How is Git different from GitHub?
questions.explanation: Git is the version control system, while GitHub is a hosting service built around Git.

choices.content: Git is the version control system, and GitHub is a hosting service.
Git is a web-based interface, and GitHub is a command-line tool.
Git is for personal use, and GitHub is for business use.
Git is used for documentation, and GitHub is used for code.

questions.content: What is a repository in GitHub?
questions.explanation: A repository in GitHub is a storage space where your project and its files are stored and managed.

choices.content: A storage space for projects and files

questions.content: What is a pull request in GitHub used for?
questions.explanation: A pull request is used to propose changes to a repository and request them to be reviewed and merged.

choices.content: Adding new features to a project

questions.content: What is the purpose of branching in Git?
questions.explanation: Branching allows developers to create independent lines of development for different features or bug fixes.

choices.content: Tracking changes made by different users

questions.content: What is a fork in GitHub?
questions.explanation: A fork is a personal copy of another user's repository that allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project.

choices.content: A personal copy of someone else's repository
A backup of your own repository
A snapshot of the project at a specific point in time

questions.content: What is a merge conflict in Git?
questions.explanation: A merge conflict occurs when Git is unable to automatically merge two branches due to conflicting changes in the same file.

choices.content: An error that occurs during repository cloning
A discrepancy in commit message formatting
Conflicting changes in the same file during merging
A failure in push/pull operations between local and remote repositories

questions.content: How do you revert a commit in Git?
questions.explanation: The "git revert" command is used to create a new commit that undoes the changes made in a previous commit.

questions.content: What is the purpose of the ".gitignore" file?
questions.explanation: The ".gitignore" file specifies intentionally untracked files that Git should ignore when making commits.

choices.content: Storing backup copies of deleted files
Ignoring files and directories from version control
Tracking changes made to project documentation

questions.content: Which of the following are advantages of using GitHub?
questions.explanation: Some advantages of using GitHub include collaborative development, version control, issue tracking, and code review.

questions.content: Which of the following Git commands are used to create a new branch?
questions.explanation: The "git branch" and "git checkout" commands are used together to create and switch to a new branch.

questions.content: How do you clone a remote repository to your local machine using Git?
questions.explanation: The "git clone" command is used to create a copy of a remote repository on your local machine.

questions.content: Which of the following Git commands are used to save changes to a local repository?
questions.explanation: The "git add" and "git commit" commands are used to save changes to a local repository.

questions.content: How do you update your local repository with the latest changes from a remote repository?
questions.explanation: The "git pull" command is used to update your local repository with the latest changes from a remote repository.

questions.content: What is a code review in GitHub?
questions.explanation: A code review is a process of reviewing and providing feedback on code changes before merging them into the main branch.

choices.content: Testing code for bugs and errors
Reviewing and providing feedback on code changes

questions.content: How can you contribute to an open-source project on GitHub?
questions.explanation: You can contribute to an open-source project on GitHub by forking the repository, making changes, and creating a pull request to propose your changes.

choices.content: Creating a new repository from scratch
Importing code from another version control system
Submitting bug reports and feature requests
Forking the repository and creating a pull request

questions.content: What is a README.md file in a GitHub repository?
questions.explanation: A README.md file is a markdown file that provides information, instructions, and documentation about the repository.

choices.content: A configuration file for the repository
A backup of the repository's commit history
A log file for tracking user activity

questions.content: What is the purpose of the "git push" command?
questions.explanation: The "git push" command is used to push local commits to a remote repository.

choices.content: Pushing local commits to a remote repository
Pulling changes from a remote repository

questions.content: What is the purpose of the "git fetch" command?
questions.explanation: The "git fetch" command is used to download remote branches and their respective commits without merging them into the current branch.

choices.content: Merging changes from a remote branch
Checking the status of local branches

questions.content: What is the purpose of the "git branch" command?
questions.explanation: The "git branch" command is used to list, create, or delete branches in Git.

choices.content: Pushing changes to a remote repository

questions.content: How do you delete a branch in Git?
questions.explanation: The "git branch -d" command is used to delete a branch in Git.

questions.content: How do you rename a branch in Git?
questions.explanation: The "git branch -m" command is used to rename a branch in Git.

questions.content: What is the purpose of the "git log" command?
questions.explanation: The "git log" command is used to view the commit history in a repository.

choices.content: Pushing changes to a remote repository

questions.content: What is the purpose of the "git stash" command?
questions.explanation: The "git stash" command is used to temporarily save changes that are not ready to be committed.

questions.content: What is the purpose of the "git revert" command?
questions.explanation: The "git revert" command is used to create a new commit that undoes the changes made in a previous commit.

choices.content: Undoing changes in a previous commit
Applying changes from a specific commit

questions.content: How do you revert a commit in Git?
questions.explanation: The "git revert" command is used to revert a commit in Git by creating a new commit that undoes the changes made in the original commit.
